messageBody:
I've never heard the term "abjad" before, but the concept is familiar
enough. I took notes all through college using a shorthand of my own
devising that was basically an "abjad." I simply used Latin consonants
(plus special characters for English consonants like "thorn" and "edh"). I
used an undotted "i" as a "vowel carrier" where necessary to prevent
ambiguity. I also had diacritics to specify vowels where I felt them
necessary.

n idhr wrdz, it lkt smthng lk dhs, bt v krs yzng dh spshl krktrz instd v
dgrfs [digraphs].

Pitman shorthand is another example of using an "abjad" to transcribe
English. The basic word forms are based on the consonantal structure.
Vowels are indicated either by the position of the consonant relative to a
baseline, or by diacritic marks added after the consonant "skeleton" has
been written. The vowel markings can often be omitted entirely.

However, because Pitman differentiates between thick and thin strokes to
distinguish voiced from unvoice consonants, it is not very practical for
most people.

Tolkien's Tengwar writing would also qualify as an "Abjad," but again, is
not so practical for everyday use.

I would be interested if you can come up with an "Abjad" for English that is
as flowing as Arabic script, but more adapted to English writing habits.

Paul


Paul

I see that no one's been posting, so I thought I'd put in my thoughts
about spelling reform and such. Personally, I don't think it should
matter how you spell something, even in Quikscript. If it was ever
adopted by any national government, it would probably be changed by
the American government to spell words the way the vast majority of
Americans pronounce words. I don't see why it matters that much,
either, because the British and the Australians and everyone else
spell words the exact same way in orthodox English spelling, even if
the pronunciation is different in their country. An example: the
word 'letter' is spelled the same way in England and Australia as it
is here. Yet, in those 2 countries, they pronounce it more
like "lettah." They don't seem to be complaining about the spelling
to anyone, or spelling it differently, so they probably wouldn't (or
shouldn't) care if we spell the words our way, they'll pronounce it
their own way anyway. That, or if someone complains, just make a
general spelling list, something not based on any particular
pronunciation (which would be difficult, I realize), which can apply
to all countries and pronunciations.

Or, another alternative, is to make an abjad for English (an alphabet
which normally only indicates consonants, but usually has a way to
indicate vowels should indication be necessary). I've been working
on one myself, and it is rather difficult, but it can be done. That
way, only the consonants, which are the constants of the words, will
remain. The vowels, the variables, can be added/changed to a
country's will. Standard spelling, however, will rarely indicate
vowels, and make everyone happy. For foreign learners of English,
vowel diacritics/letters can be added to aid them in learning the
pronunciation, like in Hebrew. Vowel letters/diacritics can also be
used to indicate pronunciation in words that would be ambiguous
otherwise (i.e. ten, tin would only be spelled 'tn').

If anyone has any comments, which I'm sure everyone does, post away.
